abstracts.cdata!:
The Andekaleka Hydroelectric Project in
            Madagascar was achieved. The Andekaleka Project was a major
            investment which made sense in the federal context of
            Madgscar's large hydro resources, high oil prices and
            projected levels of power demand. However, overly optimistic
            demand projections conveyed a sense of urgency to bring on a
            large, capital-intensive, indivisible investment. In
            hindsight, it seems that the Bank may not have fully
            appreciated the potential difficult that could rise from a
            combination of conditions prevailing t the project's
            inception (a) a financing set-up which made it difficult for
            Bank to supervise, directly, the consultants in charge of
            the project's execution, (b) parallel financing with a
            large number of co-lenders, limiting the availability of
            funds in the case of major changes in the cost estimates,
            (c) the newness of the Malagasy Electricity and Water
            Corporation (JIRAMA) as an implementing agency with the
            conspicuous absence of a financial manager, (d) the lack of
            agreement on a new tariff structure at the time of Credit
            approval and (e) a questionable data base for making
            projections of demand and financial targets. These
            conditions foreshadowed, to a certain degree, the resulting
            cost over runs, surplus hydro capacity, and difficulties for
            JIRAMA in meeting some of the financial covenants of the Credit.
